|Title=Knowing how to suspect lacrimal imperforation in infants

The lacrimal ducts are physiologically non-permeable at birth, and become perforated in the first few days of life with the first tears.

It is not uncommon for watery eyes to persist for several weeks, either unilaterally or bilaterally.

If there is swelling in the internal angle, signs of inflammation or purulent discharge, an ophthalmologist should be consulted to look for dacryocystitis (infection of the lacrimal sac).

When lacrimation is isolated, treatment consists of saline lavage with antiseptics during lacrimation episodes.

If the watering persists, a catheter can be inserted without anaesthetic from the age of 4 months.

question.title: What is typically done to treat persistent watery eyes in infants with lacrimal imperforation?
question.description: The treatment of choice for watery eyes in infants with lacrimal imperforation

option_a.title: Inserting a catheter with anaesthetic
option_a.description: A treatment option for persistent watery eyes in infants with lacrimal imperforation

option_b.title: Saline lavage with antiseptics during lacrimation episodes followed by insertion of a catheter
option_b.description: A treatment option for persistent watery eyes in infants with lacrimal imperforation

option_c.title: Observation without treatment
option_c.description: A treatment option that may be considered for mild cases of watery eyes in infants with lacrimal imperforation

option_d.title: Surgery to create a new tear duct
option_d.description: A surgical treatment option for persistent watery eyes in infants with lacrimal imperforation

correct_option.title: Saline lavage with antiseptics during lacrimation episodes followed by insertion of a catheter
